title: Synthetic Recap
body:
TORONTO (AP) — On a night where the box score read more like a video game, one man authored a masterpiece of historic proportions. Raptors guard Damon Stoudamire didn't just beat the Minnesota Timberwolves; he annihilated them, pouring in a breathtaking 48 points to carry Toronto to a thrilling 118-106 victory.

"Mighty Mouse" was colossal. Stoudamire’s electric performance wasn't just a career-high; it was a franchise-defining moment, a scoring barrage that left the Wolves scrambling for answers that simply did not exist. From deep threes to acrobatic drives, his shot-making was relentless, a one-man symphony of offensive firepower that captivated the Maple Leaf Gardens crowd.

While Stoudamire’s explosion was the main event, he was not entirely without a supporting cast. Doug Christie provided a crucial all-around effort with 20 points, 7 rebounds, and 7 assists, while Marcus Camby anchored the paint with a monstrous 17-rebound, 6-block defensive clinic. Their contributions were vital, but they were instruments in Stoudamire's concerto.

Minnesota, led by Tom Gugliotta's 24 points and 10 rebounds, fought valiantly but had no counter for a force of nature. Kevin Garnett added a solid 19 and 9, but his team was ultimately a footnote in a story about one man's transcendent night.

The final score, 118-106, tells only the smallest part of this tale. The real story was the 48 points—a number etched into the Raptors' record books, a supernova performance from their 5-foot-10 point guard that announced Toronto as a stage for the spectacular. This wasn't just a win; it was the night Damon Stoudamire delivered one for the ages.
